Gloria, age 49, is a determined person. She aims to continuously generate good income from her business. She is proud that through her daily income generated from her business, she was able to send her children to school. She has four children and all of them now hold a degree. She had been managing her small store for almost five years. She usually sells milk, coffee, sugar, shampoo, soap, canned goods and noodles to the people in her place of residence. 

Gloria needs to access a loan in the amount of P20,000 to buy school supplies such as pads of paper, crayons, folders, pencils and pens. She wants to purchase these items to diversify her business. She wants to sell more products in her store to generate a higher income. 

In the future, Gloria hopes to see her small store grow into a grocery store and make her financially stable.

loans.use: to buy school supplies such as pads of paper, crayons, folders, pencils and pens.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his business by buying more materials for his sewing.

loans.name: Duo Acucentas De Tecpan Group

texts.es:
DUO Acucentas de tecpan:
Doña Oralia es una persona trabajadora que se dedica a diferentes actividades para ayudar a su esposo y para poder sacar adelante juntos a su familia bajo su responsabilidad están sus hijos que necesitan mucho del cuidado de sus padres por eso ella solicita  un apoyo con un capital para poder ampliar mas su negocio ella se dedica a la crianza de pollos  y también se dedica a elaborar tejidos típicos a mano.y esta solicitando este credito para la compra de materia prima para la confeccion de tejido y compra de animales para la crianza La Sra. Juana Lucrecia ella se dedica a la crianza de pollos y también a elaborar tejidos típicos a mano ella realiza esta actividad porque es el único medio que tiene para apoyar a su familia esta bajo su responsabilidad una hija menor de edad ya que lo que ella anhela poder sacar  adelante a su hija y tener una educación adecuada y  una vida mejor.
texts.en:
DUO Acucentas de Tecpan:

Oralia is a hard-working person who makes a living carrying out various activities in order to help her husband and together help their family to get ahead. Her children are her responsibility and they need the care of their parents. For this reason she is requesting support with a loan in order to be able to expand her business. She makes a living raising chickens and she also makes traditional fabrics by hand. She is requesting this loan in order to buy more supplies to make fabrics and to buy animals to raise.

Juan Lucrecia makes a living raising chickens and she also makes traditional fabrics by hand. She does this because it is the only means she has to support her family. She has a daughter who is a minor under her responsibility. She wants to help her daughter get ahead, receive an adequate education and a better life.

loans.use: to buy supplies to make fabrics and to buy animals.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en: Arlene is a married woman having two children. Arlene is 43-years-old, residing at Clarin, Misamis Occidental: Philippines. Arlene owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products to earn a living and she's been 27 years in this business. Each month, she earns 10,000.00 PHP doing this type of business. She requested a loan of 15,000.00 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. In 2011, Arlene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. In the future, Arlene wants to build a house and to finished the study of her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle is from Sinusa, Ozamis City. She is 26 years old. Michelle is married and has two children. 

To make a living, Michelle owns and operates a business venture, making and selling barbecue in the local community. Michelle has been in her business for five years and earns 2,300 PHP a month for these activities.

Michelle is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional goods such as hot dogs to sell. In 2011, Michelle joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional goods such as hot dogs to sell

loans.name: Nathan

texts.en:
Nathan is married with five children between four and 17 years old. All of his children are in school. For the past 18 years, Nathan has been a farmer, producing maize and milk. He also runs a retail business in his hometown of Kitale in Western Kenya. Nathan's major business challenge is unreliable rainfall which limits his farming.

Nathan is requesting a 60,000 KES loan through Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry and build a poultry housing unit. He says that the poultry business has become very lucrative will take a shorter time to provide a good return. He adds that it is easier to run a poultry business given the area's unreliable rains and notes that other farming businesses rely a great deal on water. Nathan remains hopeful that his farming business will continue to grow.

loans.use: to buy poultry and build a poultry housing unit

loans.name: Symbat

texts.ru: Сымбат, 40 лет, замужем, мать 2 детей. Дети школьного возраста, они и супруг помогают по хозяйству. Сымбат с 2004 года занимается только полеводством, это основная деятельность семьи, начав этот бизнес с 7,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря ее упорству Сымбат достигла хороших результатов и на сегодняшний день в ее хозяйстве имеется 3,01 Га земли она выращивает фасоль, картофель и клевер. Предоставляют услуги трактора по вспашке земли. Сымбат обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом, в сумме 120,000 сом(KGS) на покупку 2 коров, она решила начать и животноводческую деятельность. Часть средств направит на полеводство. Доходы от кредита Сымбат планирует в будущем направить на обучение детей.
texts.en: Symbat is 40 years old, married, and the mother of two school-aged children.  Her children and her husband help her with the farming business.  Since 2004, Symbat has been involved in agriculture, having started with a capital of 7,000 som (KGS).  Thanks to her perseverance, Symbat has been quite successful; she now has 3.01 hectares of land on which she grows beans, potatoes and clover.  The family also provides plowing services with their tractor.  In order to increase her livestock headcount, Symbat has turned to Bai Tushum Bank CJSC and requested a loan of 120,000 som (KGS) to buy two cows.  The rest of the money will be used to cultivate her land.  In the future, Symbat will use the earnings from her loan to take care of her children's education.

loans.use: to buy two cows and to cultivate her land in order to invest in her business.

loans.name: Toeur's Group

texts.en:
Toeur, 39, is a married farmer living in Battambang province and she has three children. She makes a living through providing wedding embellishment and selling grocery items. Lack of working capital is the main challenge to her.
This is the first time for her with VisionFund, which she is leading a group of two members to get loans. She will use her loan to buy some wedding accessories to use in her service providing business. She hopes that this loan will help her grow her business to send her children to school and to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy wedding accessories to use in wedding embellishment providing business so that she can send her children to school.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth lives in Tandika area of Dar es Salaam.She is married and has three children.Two are in primary school,one in secondary school.Elizabeth runs a tailoring business in a rented premise near her residence.She has been in this business for three years now.Elizabeth is planning to increase the stock of sewing and tailoring materials.She recently get a lot of orders from nursery schools for uniforms for kids enrolled in these schools.The stock of sewing and tailoring materials she currently has cannot meet the orders.She is in need of USD 550 to have the right quantity of stock.

loans.use: Adding stock of sewing and tailoring materials

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is very hard working and focused. She bought 5 steers which were fattened and sold in three months' time. She supplements the feeds with fodder crops. Being a Maasai, she has fought against all odds to educate her girl. (Early marriage that is part of the Maasai Culture has been a hindrance to educating the girl child.)

Her plan is to buy small steers for fattening. She will sell the ready steers to the Kenya Meat Commission. She needs a loan of USD 600 to add three more steers in order to boost her income to pay school fees and repay her loan. She will pay her loan in monthly installments.

loans.use: Patricia would like to buy three steers

loans.name: Patience

texts.fr:
Patience B. was born in 1978 in Tsévié. She left middle school because of a lack of financial support. She then learned how to style hair. Through her courage, she was able to finish her apprenticeship in hairdressing and to open her own salon, which she runs beautifully. A married mother of two, she helps cover household expenses thanks to the income from her work. Through her energy and self-sacrifice, she easily managed her first loan, which she repaid without a problem.

To grow her revenues, she is requesting a loan of $800 for acquiring two hairdryers and other items. She will be able to make her business profitable and to gain a degree of financial independence.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame B. Patience est née en 1978 à Tsévié. Elle a arrêté ses études au collège par manque de support financier et apprend la coiffure. Par son courage, elle a pu terminer son apprentissage et a ouvert son propre salon qu’elle gère à merveille. Mariée et mère de deux (02) enfants, elle contribue aux charges de son foyer grâce aux revenus de son métier. Par son dynamisme et son abnégation, elle a su bien gérer son premier crédit qu’elle a remboursé sans incidence.

Pour accroître ses revenus, elle sollicite un crédit de $800 qui servira à l’achat de deux séchoirs et autres matériels. Ainsi elle pourra rentabiliser ses affaires et avoir une autonomie financière.

loans.use: Buying two hairdryers and other items

loans.name: Yaovi

texts.fr:
Born in 1962, Mr. Yaovi B. is a married father of nine children. His primary activity is agriculture. It is from this work that he provides for the needs of his family. With only a primary school education, he possesses an entrepreneurial spirit and good management abilities. After 30 years in the agriculture business, Mr. B. knows all the ins and outs of the trade. In order to combat the low yield of his lands, he is seeking financial support in the amount of $1000 to acquire fertilizers in hopes of achieving greater agricultural productivity. The sale of his products will allow him to improve his family’s living conditions. He will also augment his savings capacity.

Translated from French by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Né en 1962, Monsieur B. Yaovi est marié et père de neuf (9) enfants. Son activité principale est l’agriculture. C’est de ce travail qu’il subvient aux besoins de sa famille. Instruit de niveau primaire, il possède un bon esprit d’entreprise et une bonne capacité de gestion. Près de 30 ans d’activités agricoles, Monsieur B. Yaovi connaît tous les rouages de l’agriculture. Voulant lutter contre la pauvreté de ses terres, il sollicite un appui financier de $1000 pour s’approvisionner en fertilisants afin d’espérer à une meilleure production agricole. La vente des produits lui servira à améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Aussi pourra t-il renforcer sa capacité d’épargne.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.en: Jean Paul A., lives in Treichville (southern Abidjan), near the city hall. Born in 1976, he has more than ten years of work experience in selling bananas and other fruits in Treichville market. A. is single. He joined our micro-credit program in 2005 when he received a loan to purchase various fruits (orange, mangoes, etc.). He has performed very well since then.

loans.use: To purchase goods

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Mrs. L. Soy (age 35) and her husband PHOM Ponlok (age 51) have been married for 12 years. They have 5 children, 3 boys and two girls. Three of the children study in school. They live in a farming area along National Road 2, several kilometers south of Phnom Penh. Her husband (third from left in photo) serves in the Cambodian Army. Soy herself (not pictured), works in a nearby garment factory. Even though monthly wages of garment workers is about US $45-$50, it is considered a good job in Cambodia. Women make up 85%-90% of the factory workforces.

She is requesting this, her second loan from MAXIMA, in the amount of $800. Her family will use the funds from the loan to build a small shop in front of their house for selling groceries and other household goods. They will use the remainder of the loan to purchase inventory for the shop. After the store, which is partially built, is finished, their eldest son (far right of photo) and Soy’s mother-in-law (far left of photo) will work there. They will travel to the district market to buy inventory such as cooking oil, sugar, rice, laundry detergent, dish soap, and children’s snacks.

loans.use: To build a small shop in front of their house and to purchase groceries and other goods for inventory.

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chorn S., 45, is a mother of six children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work together on their rice paddy growing rice crops, earning collectively around $3/day in revenue. Three of her children are currently employed at a garment factory and the rest of themare students. Mrs. Chorn S. hopes to use this loan to purchase more seeds and some farming tools for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds and some farming tools for her business.

loans.name: Merta Giri Kusuma Group

texts.id:
Merta Giri Kusuma group, located in Candikusuma village, was formed by several community members who were interested in raising hogs. They learned that Dinari foundation will provide assistance and financial loan for those who are interested in hogs farming. The eight member group, chaired by I Nengah Reka, Dayu Ketut Sukeni as secretary and Ni Komang Suparwati as treasurer, is requesting for the financial loan and technical assistance to Dinari foundation. After obtaining proper training and assistance, such as how to raise the hogs and not wasting money on animal feed and how to quickly manage hogs desease, Merta Giri Kusuma group is seeking financial loan from Dinari Foundation to buy quality piglets and animal feed. By doing so it hopes to provide better results than that of doing a more traditional hogs farming that some members used to do in the past. With the asssitance and financial support from the Dinari Foundation, the Merta Giri Kusuma is poised that its business will be growing well and succesful.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Kelompok Merta Giri Kusuma berlokasi di dusun Candikusuma, terbentuk karena keinginan dari beberapa masyarakat yang menekuni usaha beternak babi Karena mereka mendengar berita bahwa Yayasan Dinari memberi pembinaan serta pinjaman modal untuk masyarakat yang ingin mengembangkan usaha beternak babi. Dengan anggota sebanyak 8 orang ,yang diketuai oleh I Nengah Reka, Sekretaris Dayu Ketut Sukeni dan bendahara Ni Komang Suparwati, maka kelompok Merta Giri Kusuma mengajukan permohonan pinjaman dan pembinaan tersebut ke Yayasan Dinari. Setelah mendapat pembinaan serta pelatihan yang cukup seperti bagaimana cara beternak babi yang baik dan benar,cara mengatur keuangan rumah tangga agar modal untuk beternak babi tidak habis untuk biaya makan serta cara penanggulangan penyakit babi yang cepat dan tepat, maka Kelompok Merta giri Kusuma mendapat pinjaman modal dari Yayasan Dinari untuk membeli bibit unggul dan pakan ternak yang berkwalitas ,maksudnya agar hasil yang diperoleh akan lebih bagus daripada memelihara babi lokal ,yang selama ini mereka tekuni. Dengan adanya pembinaan dan dukungan Modal dari Yayasan Dinari maka kelompok Merta Giri Kusuma berkeyakinan bahwa usahanya akan sukses dan berkembang bagus.

loans.use: To buy quality piglets and animal feed

loans.name: Getina

texts.en:
Greetings from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! Getinda M. is 48 years odl. She is married and has four children, who are between the ages of 18 and 30. She has two other dependents, who are her nieces.

Getinda owns a barbecue chicken business. Getinda has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA. She now requests a new loan in order to purchase additional ingredients and utensils in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-credit worthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. When a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients and utensils for her barbecue chicken business

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan C. is native of the rural community Francisco I. Madero in the city of Victoria in Tamaulipas. Oranges is the largest crop in this area. The majority of the people make a living in this business because there are not many other sources of employment or other opportunities.

He started his business more than 13 years ago, first selling oranges in the area and later also in the city since this increased his market. The good thing about this business is that oranges always sell and at times the orders are large. Thanks to this he has been able to move his family ahead. He has two children, which back then were 10 and 12 years old. That is the reason why upon running out of money he started his own business of selling oranges to obtain some income. Currently he does not have so many financial problems because he is only responsible for the expenses of his house and of his wife and himself.

He is requesting a loan of USD $575 which he will repay in 6 months, it will help him obtain product and help cover the cost of transporting the product. Let us help Don Juan so that he can continue working!

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Juan C. es originario del ejido Francisco I. Madero en Cd Victoria, Tamaulipas en este lugar la naranja es lo que mas se cosecha, y la mayoría de la gente de allí es a lo que se dedica ya que en el pueblo no hay muchas fuentes de empleo por lo que no tienen otras áreas de oportunidad.

Su negocio comenzó hace mas de 13 años, vendiendo naranjas al principio en el ejido y después también en la ciudad porque de esa manera lograba ocupar mas mercado. Lo bueno de su negocio es que la naranja siempre se vende y en ocasiones hasta se hacen pedidos grandes. Gracias a esto he podido sacar adelante a su familia tiene 2 hijos que en ese entonces tenían 10 y 12 años, por esa razón al no haber dinero tuvo que poner su propio negocio de venta de naranjas para obtener algo de dinero. Actualmente ya no tiene tantos problemas económicos porque solo solventa los gastos de su casa y los de su esposa y el.

Requiere un crédito de US $575 que pagara en 6 meses esto le va ayudar para poder surtir producto y para el transporte del producto. Ayudemos a don Juan para que pueda seguir trabajando!!!.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 22 year old Rose K.. She is married and has a one year old child. She also has two dependents, who live with her because they are her sisters. In 2003, Rose established her market stall business. Rose has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA. She now requires a new loan in order to purchase stock of crops in bulk for resale. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility, as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk for resale at the market.

loans.name: Julieta Abilio

texts.en:
Julieta is 32 years old and originally from the Gaza Province. She has a boyfriend and a 3-year-old daughter.

Julieta moved with her family to Matola, a village 15Km away from the capital city Maputo, when young. She studied until 7th grade and stopped in 1993 because she moved to South Africa to live with her sister. Julieta lived in South Africa until 2005, and there she worked with commerce, selling products and food in the street. Julieta met her boyfriend and moved in with him a few months later. Julieta decided to come back to Mozambique because according to her “life in Mozambique is prettier and nicer”. She has a small stand in the street where she sells food, such as tomatoes, rice, peanut, onions and garlic. Julieta makes between MTn 500 to MTn 1,000 per day. Julieta’s best business is the wholesale products of things she brings from South Africa. Julieta goes to South Africa at least once a month and brings many products that clients request and others that she knows she will easily sell, such as crackers. Julieta has to accumulate at least 3,000 Rands to make sure she can buy enough products, pay the transport and also the customs duties. Every 3 months Julieta benefits from her business in South Africa and goes visit her boyfriend who still lives there.

Together with her boyfriend (a Mozambican man from Maputo), Julieta bought land in Matola and started to build a house. The first MTn 8,000 loan with Hluvuku was used to pay half of the salary of the construction workers. They were asking MTn 16,000 and Julieta just had half of the money, and preferred to use a known institution than any man in the street. With this second loan of MTn 10,500 Julieta plans to continue building her house. She will buy windows, doors and 10 aluminum-roofing plaques to finish the bedrooms and the living room.

In the future, Julieta would like to get married (officially), finish her house with a bathroom and build a fence around her house. Julieta would also like to build a proper general store to sell many products and increase her daily income.

loans.use: Buy construction material

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa E., 35, and her husband, Mr. Chhorn Cheng, 40, who live on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometres from Phnom Penh, were married in 1988 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in school and the youngest one stays at home.

Mrs. Channa has been a silk weaver for twenty years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the village trader, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh.  Mr. Chhorn has been a construction worker since 1993. Mrs. Channa is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Ramon

texts.es:
Ramón began his business to improve and offer a better quality of life for his family. He wasn’t able to find good work that would give him the opportunity to improve and be able to have better income for his family, so he decided to begin his own business in 2002, selling tools and scrap metal. He began with little merchandise, and upon seeing that he could earn an income he continued working hard to make his business successful.

He needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to buy merchandise and be able to continue with his business. With your support Ramón will be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Ramon inicio el negocio para tratar de mejorar y poder darle mejor calidad de vida a su familia. En ese momento no encontraba un buen trabajo que le diera la oportunidad de mejorar y poder tener mejores ingresos para su familia, por lo que decidio emprender su propio negocio, comenzo en el año 2002 con la venta de herramienta y chatarra, con muy poca mercancia, al ver que si le podia redituar siguio esforzandose para sacar adelante su negocio.

El necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mercancia y poder seguir con su negocio. Con tu apoyo Ramon saldra adelante.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Bernardina Delia

texts.es:
Delia is a member of the communal bank called "Divine Love". She's 54 years old. She's married and a has 3 children. Delia runs a bakery out of her own home where she makes a local type of bread called 'Chapla' which is native to the area. She has a wood burning oven. She has hired some help to relieve her from running the bakery. She also has a small grocery store and phone booths where the locals can make long-distance phone calls. Her hours of operation are 5 in the morning to 10 at night.

Delia would like to purchase flour in bulk with this loan. Her dreams are to be able to continue to work and to provide a college education for her children.

Translated by a Kiva Volunteer.

Primer Préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=15172&_tpos=8&_tpg=2

Delia es socia del Banco Comunal Amor Divino.

Delia es casada, tiene 54 años y 3 hijos, Delia tiene una panadería en su casa, en donde elabora el pan típico de la zona llamado “Chapla”, el horno es rustico de leña, para lo cual cuenta con la ayuda de operarios, sus ventas lo realiza en el mismo horno. Además Delia tiene una tienda de abarrotes y también tiene locutorios telefónicos, el horario de atención son de 5 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche.

Delia necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de sacos de harina. Los sueños de Delia son seguir trabajando para salir adelante, sus hijos sigan estudiando hasta ser profesionales.

loans.use: To purchase flour in bulk

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es: Ruth es una muchachita de 18 años, a su corta edad, es propietaria de un taller de artesanía de tejidos, lugar donde ofrece trabajo a otros dos jóvenes, con quienes hacen un equipo perfecto para el cumplimiento de sus pedidos.Ella adquirió sus conocimientos de su madre, quien con paciencia y dedicación le inculcó este bello  arte.Actualmente  se dedica a la confección de hermosos y coloridos chuchos, chalinas, medias y guantes, que son vendidos al por mayor  en la ciudad capital, Lima. El deseo de esta joven es adquirir materia prima para cumplir con sus  pedidos y seguir prosperando en este noble oficio que la va llenando de satisfacciones.
texts.en:
Ruth is a young 18 year old woman, and at her young age, she is the owner of a workshop for fabric artisanry, where she offers work to to other young people, who make a perfect team for completing their orders. She acquired her knowledge from her mother, who with patience and dedication taught her this beautiful art. Actually she makes beautiful and colorful chuchos, chalinas, medias and gloves, which are sold mostly in the capital city, Lima. The hope of this young woman is to acquire fine material to complete her orders and continue prospering in this noble work which is filling her with satisfaction.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing the material she uses for her work

loans.name: Zuhro

texts.ru: Гоибова Зухро жительница Джиликульского района. Возраст 38 лет, замужем и имеет пятерых детей. Уже четыре года занимается торговлей. Рядом с домом имеет магазин , где торгует продуктами питания. Бизнес приносит доход , но ей необходимо улучшить условия в магазине. Поэтому она решила получить кредит для того , чтобы купить стройматериалы для ремонта в помещении. Это поможет ей привлечь клиентов , а так же улучшить условия хранения продуктов питания. Погасить кердит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Zuhro G. lives in the Jillikuli region. She is 38 years old, married and has five children. For the last four years Zuhro has been working in retail - she owns and manages the grocery store next to her house. Her business is profitable but she needs to improve the building in which the store is located. Zuhro wants to take out a loan in order to purchase construction supplies for the remodeling of her store. This will not only attract new clients but also improve the storage conditions of groceries she offers for sale. Zuhro is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Store remodelling

loans.name: Antoinnette

texts.fr: Antoinnette K. est âgée de 42 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle est propriétaire d’une boutique d’alimentation générale depuis 7 ans à Wome, un village situé à environ 130 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle désire par ce crédit accroître la taille de son commerce en approvisionnant sa boutiques afin de mieux satisfaire la clientèle. Cette opportunité lui permettra de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Antoinnette K., 42, is married and the mother of 3 children. For 7 years, she has been the owner of a general store in Womé, a village situated about 130 km from Lomé, the capital of Togo. She wants to use this loan to expand the size of her business by stocking her store so that she can better satisfy her clientele. This opportunity will permit her to better support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase merchandise for re-sale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose Z. sells beer and is requesting a loan to buying more stock. Rose is 28 years old and married. Her husband is a casual worker. She has three children and they all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to continue to pay their school fees. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more beer to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy toys and fireworks

loans.name: Olim

texts.ru: Алиев Олим житель района Шахринау. Очень молодой , но амбициозный молодой человек. Женат , детей пока нет. работает таксистом , хотя имеет высшее образование. Так как деятельность приносит хорошую прибыль. Тем не менее обратился за кредитом , для того , чтобы на полученные деньги  купить автозапчасти. Это поможет сделать капитальный ремонт и таки образом улучшить качество обслуживания  и привлечь новых клиентов.
texts.en:
Olim A. lives in the Shahrinaw district. He is a young but ambitious man. He is married, so far without children. He works as a taxi driver even though he completed university, because that work provides a good income. Still, he is requesting a loan which he will use to buy spare parts. This will help him complete major repairs and in doing so improve the quality of service he offers and attract new customers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle repair

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Men K., 49, pictured here with her husband, has a business selling palm sugar to earn a living, and she is able to make US$ 12 in revenue per day. Every day, she purchases raw palm juice and refines it to palm sugar. She then sells it to the market-wholesaler.

Her husband is a farmer who grows and sells yams. On average, he makes around US$ 1.50 in profit a day. This couple has three children, two of whom are employed and one in school.

Mrs. Men is asking for a loan to buy more palm juice so she can make more palm sugar to sell at the market.

loans.use: palm juice

loans.name: Reida

texts.en:
Reida G. is currently in the business of selling "simsim" (sesame) and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Reida is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: expand her business

loans.name: Nora,

texts.es:
Con cincuenta y ocho años, Nora aun tiene muchos planes que desea cumplir en el futuro. Ella además D. ser una gran microempresaria, también es una madre ejemplar, pues solo con su trabajo se ha encargado D. cuidar a sus tres hijos ella sola. Ellos ya son mayores e independientes, gracias al esfuerzo D. Nora.

En uj inicio Nora ha sido docente D. educación inicial y primaria trabajando en colegios. Tiempo después se animo por tener un negocio propio, por lo que compro un puesto en el mercado. Hoy el negocio ya tiene ocho años, y lo que en un inicio era solo tienda D. abarrotes se ha convertido en un bazar, pues no solo venD. abarrotes, también bebidas y artículos varios.

Por otro lado, hace tres años decidió aprovechar su tiempo en casa también vendiendo gaseosas y cervezas por la tarD. y en la noche. Ahora lo que ella más quiere es tener un negocio  mucho más granD. y menos pesado para la edad que tiene. Quisiera abrir un restaurante o una librería en su casa.
texts.en:
At 58 years old, Nora still has many plans she hopes to fulfill in the future. Besides being a great small businesswoman, she's also an exemplary mother, since while working she took care of raising her 3 children by herself. They are now older and independent, thanks to Nora's efforts. In the beginning, Nora was an elementary school teacher working in schools. Later, she became excited about having her own business, so she bought a place in the market. Now her business has been going for 8 years, and what began as only a grocery store has become a bazaar. She not only sells groceries but also drinks and various goods. On the other hand, it's been 3 years since she decided to take advantage of her time at home by also selling sodas and beer in the afternoon and in the evening. Now, what she wants most is to have a bigger business that is less difficult for a woman her age. She wants to open a restaurant or a library at home.

Translated from Spanish by Julie Lutz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: At 33, Norma L. finds a way to help her husband sustain their daily living. She is married to Joel L. and blessed with 4 children. They are engaged in a bakery business wherein her husband is the baker and she is the one who vends the baked bread to their neighbors and nearby villages. Norma is happy with what they have started and plans to improve the business. She wants to receive a loan from HSPFI in the amount of PHP 4,000 to have additional capital for their existing business.

loans.use: Additional capital for a bakery

location.town: Zone 12, Bunawan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Djavid

texts.en: Djavid was born in 1977. He lives in Khachmaz town. 4 years ago he started this business. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy foodstuffs to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs for re-sale

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita A. is 35 years old. She is married and blessed with three children. Two of them go to school. Her husband works as a miner in the traditional way and sometimes in farming. Nenita wants to help her husband in providing all their needs even in just a simple way. She entered into a business preparing snacks (like fried bananas) and peddles them near the pamilingan where all traditional gold miners do their work, and around the village where she already has her usual customers.

Nenita now is applying for loan from HSPFI, a KIVA partner. The money that will be released to her will be used to purchase enough bananas for her business, part will be spend for the enrollment of her children in school, and the rest for the needs of the family. Nenita is optimistic about all her plans for her business and her family.

loans.use: Bananas for chip production; school fees; family expenses

location.town: Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kerambo

texts.en: Kerambo C. is a married man and an entrepreneur in Tanzania. He runs two businesses at Yombo Buza ward in Dar es Salaam. He runs a poultry business, raising both layers and broilers, and at the same time he runs two retail shops where he employs two workers.  He sells fifteen trays of eggs a day to both retail and wholesale customers. He has 1,500 broilers and layers. Necessary items for his businesses are purchased from the wholesale and retail shops at the Kariakoo city shopping center. He is asking for a loan to build more poultry cages and to buy what he needs to keep the businesses going.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba N. sells fish. She goes to the shore to buy fresh fish and then smokes it before selling it at the market at Kormatse near Cape Coast which she has been doing since 2002. Aba has no educational background. She is married and has four children; her husband is a fisherman

She is responsible for paying for her children’s education. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy more fish to sell at the market. She hopes to use the profits she gains to further expand her business.

loans.use: increase her capital to buy more fish to sell at the market

loans.name: Alisher

texts.en:
I. Alisher is 30 years old. He is married and has two children. He is a hard-working man struggling to feed his children and parents (who are living with him) by selling national fabrics for national dresses. Alisher has a trading place in the center local market of Dushanbe city. All the fabrics are supplied from the neighboring town of Istaravshan. Alisher is trying to have a wide range of goods to meet the requirements of his customers and to satisfy the needs of the clients with different levels of income. Alisher, being a devoted father, is doing all the best in order for his children to be well educated and to make them happy. Today Alisher feels that with more working capital his business could generate more income, so he is asking for a loan of 5000 Somoni to jumpstart the business and raise the family's standard of living. Let's help this incredible father give his children a brighter future.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase his inventory of fabric

loans.name: Dayse

texts.es:
Dayse es socia del Banco Comunal Rikchariy que significa Despierta en quechua.
Dayse es conviviente, tiene 21 años y 2 hijos, Dayse se dedica a la elaboración de chocolates con relleno de manera artesanal, sus ventas los realiza a las tiendas por mayor, además Dayse viaja a la feria de Huamanguilla en donde compra maíz y lo vende en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Dayse necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de maíz y papa.
Los sueños de Dayse son tener una tienda propia y ser empresaria.
texts.en:
The name of Dayse’s Community Bank is Rikchariy, which means wake up in Quechua. Dayse, 21, is in a common law marriage and has two children. Dayse makes hand made, filled chocolates. She sells to wholesale stores. Dayse also travels to the fair in Huamanguilla to buy corn. She sells it in the Abastos market in the city of Ayacucho. Dayse needs a loan for 1,050 PEN to buy corn and potatoes. Dayse’s dreams are to have her own store and to become an entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn and potatoes

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has a small shop where he sells motor-vehicle spare parts. Peter has been in this business for the past 15 years. He previously worked in a petrol station. Peter is requesting a third loan of Ksh. 80,000 to increase his stock of spare parts.

Peter is married and has seven children and eight grandchildren. While his family used to live in the Rift Valley, after the post-election violence in Kenya, Peter was forced to relocate his entire family to Nairobi. He hopes to use the profits from his growing business to build his family a home. Peter describes himself as humble, determined and social.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable micro-finance institution that offers savings and credit services to more than 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add stock of spare parts

loans.name: Afia

texts.en: Afia is 40, married and has three sons and three daughters; all are in school. She works very hard to support her husband to provide for the family. They live in a rented apartment in Oda in the Eastern region of Ghana. She is a trader. and runs a provision store. Her store is by the roadside in her community. Afia procures her raw materials from nearby towns at moderate prices. She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy provision

loans.name: Fransisca

texts.en: Fransisca sells cooked foods and drinks in her shop. The demands for her cooked foods are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is 38 years old and married with 2 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase a generator because there is constant power failure in her community. This she says will enable her sell cold drinks to her customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase a generator

loans.name: Hiyam

texts.en: Hiyam is a 30-year-old single woma living with her parents. She has been working as an accountant since 2002. in order to develop her work, Hiyam is requesting her loan of $1,000 to buy a table to facilitate her work and adding new decoration.

loans.use: buy a table to facilitate her work and adding new decoration

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence T. is the leader of her lending group in Bushenyi. She is a 39-year-old married woman with five children. Her children are between the ages of 7 and 17 years old, and she takes care of three orphans.

For the past five years, Florence has been engaged in the business of running a restaurant/hotel in Rweibare III. By doing so, she is able to earn approximately 200,000 UGX of profit per week. If Florence had had additional capital, she claims that she would have generated more profit because of her strategic positioning. Due to limited capital, she lacks funding to purchase additional food stuffs and restaurant materials (e.g., plates, cups, spoons, folks, and chairs).

In the future, Florence would like to expand her restaurant, and she would like for all of her children to be educated at the university level. As such, Florence is seeking a loan to help her build a new building for her restaurant. She explains that loans have always enabled her to buy enough food for her customers.

loans.use: To build a new (and improved/expanded) restaurant

loans.name: Hakikat

texts.en:
R. Hakikat is a very responsible and hard working girl. Four years ago, she started working as a seamstress working in a local workshop. Hakikat has a big family and that was the reason she has started her own business. She makes traditional woman dresses. She asks for a loan of $800 USD that will be invested in buying supplies to increase her production and cover her customers' demands. Help this family with improving the quality of their life by contributing to the growth of Hakikat’s business. They sincerely thank you for it.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics to make traditional women dresses.

loans.name: Sebastiao Joao

texts.pt:
Sebastião João M. nasceu no Distrito de Inharrime, Província de Inhambane, tem 40 anos de idade casado e pai de 2 filhos de 12 e 6 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. É bacharel em engenharia agrícola, formado na Holanda. Vive na casa própria com a sua família, sustenta 2 irmãos e sobrinhos enviando algum valor para o seu sustento.

Saiu de Inharrime para Maputo em 1988, para continuar com os estudos, depois de concluir no Instituto Agrário de Boane, viajou para Holanda onde fez o seu bacharelado. Trabalha como técnico Agrónomo a 17 anos, das 8h as 16h, e tem um salário mensal de 12.530, poupa algum valor na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu amigo que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 5º empréstimo no valor de 26.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pagamento de mão de obra, e ferro) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. Os anteriores créditos foram de 16.000.00mt, 15.000.00mt, 25.000.00mt e 40.000.00mt todos foram para a mesma actividade.

O objectivo é de ver a sua obra terminada para oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família. Futuramente pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para construir um estabelecimento comercial e abrir sua machamba.
texts.en:
Sebastião João M. was born in the district of Inharrime in the province of Inhambane. He is 40, married, and the father of 2 children who are 12 and 6. Both of them go to school. He has a bachelor's degree in agricultural engineering, which he received in Holland. He lives in his own home with his family, and he supports his 2 brothers and their children by sending them some money. He left Inharrime for Maputo in 1988 to continue his studies. After he finished studying at the Agrarian Institute in Boane, he traveled to Holland where he got his bachelor's degree. He has worked as an agricultural technician for 17 years. He works from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. and makes a monthly wage of 12,530 meticais. He saves some of it in his bank account. He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through his friend who is also a client of the institution. This is his 5th loan, and it is for 26,000 meticais. He will use it to purchase construction materials (cement, iron, and to pay for labor) to continue building his home. His previous loans were for 16,000, 15,000, 25,000, and 40,000 meticais. All of them were used for the same purpose. His goal is to finish his home so he can offer better living conditions to his family. In the future he hopes to request more loans to build a commercial establishment and to start a small farm.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials and to pay for labor

loans.name: Santos Maria

texts.es: Doña Santos Maria G. vive en la colonia Peña Vieja es una zona que esta bien poblada, las calles son pavimentadas, las casas están de forma continua y cuenta con todos los servicios publicos, tiene 26 años de experiencia en la elaboracion de tortillas, compra el maiz para molerlo y la leña en un carro repartidor de leña, asimismo entrega un pedido de doscientos lempiras todos los días en una Institución de Gobierno que se llama Fundacion de Aldeas Infantiles (SOS), para ir a este lugar toma un bus que tarda en llegar una hora y le cuesta 3 lempiras, lo hace de lunes a viernes, vive con su esposo y su suegra, la cual tiene 80 años de edad y sus dos hijas. sus hijas en la mañana le ayudan a elaborar las tortillas ya que en la tarde van a la universidad y de esta forma doña Maria a podido salir adelante. Santos solicita el credito para comprar mas materia prima para elaborar mas tortillas y con las ganancias que obtenga hacer mejoras a su vivienda ya que la quiere ver mas grande. Doña maria invierte mensualmente $ 240.60 y vende $560.00 obteniendo una ganacia mensual de $ 319.40
texts.en:
Santos Maria G. lives in the neighborhood of Peña Vieja, which is a well-populated area with paved roads, attached houses and all public services. She has 26 years of experience preparing tortillas. She purchases the corn to grind and buys firewood from a distribution wagon. In turn, she delivers an order worth 200 lempiras [the local currency] every day to a governmental institution called the Children's Villages Foundation (SOS). To reach this location, she rides the bus, which takes an hour and costs her 3 lempiras. She does this Monday through Friday. She lives with her husband, her 80-year-old mother-in-law, and her two daughters. In the morning, her daughters help her prepare the tortillas, since they go to the university in the afternoon. In this way, Santos Maria has been able to get ahead. She is requesting the current loan to purchase ingredients and supplies to prepare more tortillas. With the profits she obtains, she will make improvements to her house, since she would like it to be larger. Santos Maria invests $240.60 in her business each month and has sales of $560.00, for a monthly profit of $319.40.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing corn, water, firewood, matches and lime

loans.name: Altangerel

texts.en: Altangerel is 31 years old and lives with his mother and younger siblings in a house in Uvurkhangai province, Mongolia. He supports his family by operating a motorcycle sales and repair business in his town. He sells a variety of Chinese motorcycles to the public. Due to the rough terrain and lack of roads in the Mongolian countryside, motorcycles are a popular form of transportation. Altangerel started his business in 2007 after helping his mother manage her consumer goods business for two years. He has gained much experience and earned a positive reputation amongst his customers. His earnings have enabled him to buy a house and yard for his family. Altangerel is a very open-minded businessman and is known for his good character. He is focused on the future and says, “I want to continue to improve my business.” He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase motorcycle parts for his business.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle parts

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie V. runs a fishing business. She is 28 years old, married and has two children who are currently attending school. She lives in the village of Lao Sta Cruz in Plaridel, Misamis Occidental and has been fishing for two years now. She earns about P15,000 a month in the business.

Elvie joined PMPC in 2008. She was interested in the various products and services offered, as well as the opportunity to expand her business. She has taken out a previous loan of P15,000 and is now at her fourth loan with PMPC. Elvie is requesting a loan of P30,000 and looks forward to using the loan proceeds to purchase more equipment for her fishing business. She hopes to use her profits to repay her loan, as well as to make sure she can provide for her children. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To buy additional equipment for her fishing business

location.town: Plaridel-Lao Sta. Cruz, Plaridel, Misamis Occident

loans.name: Alima

texts.en: Alima S. is currently in the business of selling cereals like sorghum, maize, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock beans and pulses (groundnuts, peas, cowpeas) to sell. Alima is 18 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bigger store. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy beans and pulses to sell

loans.name: Djiguitougou Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Djiguitougou ont en moyenne 32 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles  traditionnelles au quartier Guegnéka de la ville de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république.
Ces femmes se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de fruits et légumes, de céréales, du savon, des tubercules, des chaussures, des habits  et la fabrication de l’encens.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe sont à leur  cinquième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, quelques chargements de charrettes en patates douces, oranges et tomates, des colis d’habits pour enfants et pagnes wax, des cartons de savons, des ingrédients pour l’encens et quelques paires de chaussures pour femmes.
Elles s’approvisionnent  sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui servira à essentiellement étoffer leur fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group Djiguitougou average 32 years of age and four children each living in traditional families in the Guegnéka district of the city of Fana, prefecture of Dioila (2nd administrative region of the republic).  These women know one another by community ties, and they do commerce in a variety of items, such as fruit and vegetables, grains, soap, tubers, footwear, and clothing. And they make incense. After having properly repaid the four preceding loans, the group members are now on their fifth solidarity loans that will be used to buy a few cart-loads of sweet potatoes, oranges, and tomatoes; packages of children's clothing; pagnes (colorful West African cloth); boxes of soap;  ingredients for incenses; and a few pairs of women's shoes.  Supplies are gotten locally from producers and wholesalers, and sales are made at the market.  Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of women and men.  The group members each envision making an average monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for building up their working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a variety of goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional cloth and other materials required for making clothes

loans.name: Shadrack

texts.en:
Shadrack O. O. is 30 old, married and has three children who are all in primary school. His business is located at Manyatta estate, a highly populated and busy market in Kisumu. He sells dining tables, coffee tables, wall units and couches. He has been doing this business for six years now and has two employees. 

Shadrack says that this business is profitable. The major challenge he has is limited space to display his products. He is using his loan of Kes 60,000 to buy more timber to grow his business. He hopes to produce in large scale and open up a display center in Kibuye, Kisumu. He is very hardworking, humble and reliable.

loans.use: To purchase timber in order to expand his business

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.en: Anastacia D. is from the village of Balon, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Anastacia owns and operates a food stall, selling baked goods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. Anastacia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from PMPC. Anastacia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Corina

texts.es:
Corina vive en la  zona de Puerto Mejillones  de la ciudad de El Alto con sus hijos los cuales se encuentran en edad escolar,  su esposo es chofer de transporte publico.
 
Corina comercializa chuño, tunta y queso, alimentos que vende al por menor en los mercados de la ciudad.

El crédito lo destinará  como aumento de capital de trabajo para comprar sus productos en mayor cantidad para abastecer la demanda que tiene. 
 
Es el segundo  crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Corina lives in the Puerto Mejillones area of the city of el Alto with her school aged children; her husband is a public transportation driver. Corina sells chuño (freeze-dried potato), tunta (Andean potato) and cheese at retail to various markets in the city. She will use the funds to increase her working capital to buy products in larger amounts to satisfy customer demand. This is her 2nd loan with Impro and the socio-economic evaluation undertaken indicates that she qualifies for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy large quantities of freeze-dried potato, Andean potato and cheese.

loans.name: Narcisa Angela

texts.es:
La señora Narcisa pertenece al banco comunal Los Bajos de Montecristi en la provincia de Manabí ella nació en ese bello lugar rodeado de mucha vegetación y con atractivos turísticos para propios y extraños.

Narcisa Esta casada tiene 38 años, y con dos niños, se graduó muy joven en belleza en una academia de la ciudad y se dedica desde hace 5 años a ejercer lo aprendido decidió en tener su propio gabinete de belleza en su casa, donde realiza corte de cabellos, tientes, peinados y maquillaje, ella esta en constante seminarios para aprender mas de las ultimas tendencias en belleza, esta casada desde hace 20 años y el esposo la apoyo mucho el sabe que ama el trabajo, ha podido ir incrementando su local gracias a la iniciativa de una amiga que le comentó de la Fundación y la motivó y ya han transcurrido 8 ciclos que viene trabajando de la mano de Espoir.

Con este nuevo crédito la señora Narcisa podrá comprar productos como shampoo, tintes, maquillaje y demás productos necesarios para su peluquería, el día que más trabajo tiene es el sábado y los demás días va a domicilio a pedido de sus clientas. El sueño de nuestra socia es poder tener una peluquería mas completa en la ciudad de Manta.
texts.en:
Mrs. Narcisa belongs to the Los Bajos de Montecristi Communal Bank in the province of Manabí. She was born in this lovely region, surrounded by much vegetation and tourist attractions for locals and outsiders. Narcisa is married, 38 years old, and has 2 children. She graduated very young from beauty school in the city and after dedicating herself for 5 years to practicing what she learned, she decided to open her own beauty shop in her house. There she cuts hair, tints, and does permanents and make up. She constantly attends seminars to learn more about the latest tendencies in beauty. Narcisa has been married 20 years and her husband helps her a great deal, understanding that she loves the work. She has been expanding her shop, thanks to the initiative of a friend who recommended her to the Foundation and motivated her. She has now completed 8 loan cycles, working with ESPOIR. With this new loan, Narcisa will be able to buy products like shampoo, tints, make up and other things needed in her beauty shop. Her busiest day is Saturday and on other days, she goes by request to her customers' homes. Her dream is to be able to have a more complete beauty salon in the city of Manta.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING TINTS, SHAMPOO, AND MAKE UP FOR HER BEAUTY SALON

loans.name: Keur Maïssa Gaye Group

texts.fr:
Le Groupe de KEUR MAÏSSA G. est un groupement de promotion féminin composé essentiellement de femmes issues toutes du même village. Il a été créé en 2003 sous l'influence  de la solidarité et l'affinité qui règne entre les femmes. Après 07 ans d'existence et d'expérience  par rapport à l'organisation de groupe, les femmes ont démarché auprès de l'Institution de Microfinance CAURIE-MF pour bénéficier de ses services financiers. C'est ainsi que le 29 avril 2010 qu'elle ont été érigées en Banc Villageois qui porte le même nom que le Groupe et le village. Elles ont reçu leur premier financement le 17 mai 2010 lors de son inauguration. 
Les trois quarts des membres sont mariées et mères d'au moins de 02 enfants et la moyenne d'âge est 40 ans. 

Quant à la Présidente du Banc Villageois Madame Awa N., elle est âgée de 47 ans et mère de 4 enfants en charge. Elle fait de l'élevage et avec son prêt elle envisage acheter 4 chèvres qu'elle va emboucher pendant au moins 4 mois pour les revendre au niveau du grand marché hebdomadaire de son village. Elle pratique cette activité depuis 3 ans. Et pour ne pas trop dépenser pour l'alimentation de ses sujets, elle collecte du foin à la fin de l'hivernage et le sécher afin de mieux le conserver. Son objectif est de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille par une contribution par rapport à la nourriture, la santé et l'habillement de ses enfants. Ses bénéfices lui permettent également de satisfaire ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
KEUR MAÏSSA G. is a women's promotion group composed mainly of women from the same village. It was founded in 2003, inspired by the solidarity and affinity that exists between the women. After the group had existed for seven years and the women had gained experience in group organization, they approached the micro-finance institution, CAURIE-MF, to make use of their financial services. Thus, on April 29, 2010, they became a Banc Villageois with the same name as their group and the village. They received their first loan on May 17, 2010 when they were inaugurated. Three quarters of the members are married and have at least two children; the average age of the women is 40. The President of the Banc Villageois, Madame Awa N., is 47 and has four children. She farms livestock and plans to use her loan to buy four goats, which she will raise for at least four months before selling them in the large weekly market in her village. She has been doing this for three years. In order to reduce feeding costs, she collects hay at the end of the rainy season and dries it so that it keeps better. Her goal is to help improve her family's standard of living by contributing to the cost of food, health care and clothing for her children. Her earnings also allow her to satisfy her own personal needs.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To finance various revenue-generating activities

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mrs. Cheng V. was born in 1973 and is currently living in a village near Phnom Penh, the capital. She earns her daily living by growing various vegetables on her own land in her village. Since 2005, Cheng V. has sold her mature crops to her buyers every two or three months after she plants. Her husband is a domestic construction worker. This couple has three young children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory, while one attends school. Cheng V. has requested a loan to repair her motorcycle that often breaks down when she uses it to commute.

loans.use: To repair a motorcycle.

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
Y. Munira is a mother of 4 children. She is a very honorable and resolute woman. Ever since she was a young girl, she learned the honest work of raising cattle, the knowledge she has passed down to her own children who have also managed to improve their quality of life. 

Munira and her husband started their livestock business with only one cow. After a number of sacrifices they were able to increase little by little the quantity of calves. At the moment, with the support of their children, they have started to produce milk. They sell it on the weekends in their village. 

Currently Munira wants to expand her business and to purchase more cattle. With the desire of improving their living conditions, Munira is counting on your generous heart. 
  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing  calves to raise

loans.name: Tlacpacame Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama tlacpacame, que significa “L. D. arriba”  en náhuatl, su lengua nativa. Está ubicado en el Estado D. Puebla en México.  El grupo está conformado por  10 integrantes.
Josefina G.M. presidenta del grupo. Tiene 49 años, no tiene estudios, casada, comerciante y tiene en total 9 hijos: 5 mujeres y 4 varones D. L. cuales solo 3 son menores D. edad y dependen D. ella económicamente.  Ella se dedica a la compra venta D. ajos, negocio que inició hace más D. 15 años ya que la comunidad a la pertenece se identifica como gran productora D. ajo a nivel nacional, incluso se pueD. percibir en ocasiones su olor con tan sólo ir caminando por sus calles. Solicita el préstamo para comprar ajo D. mayoreo y poder obtener un buen precio que le permita una mayor ganancia. Sus clientes opinan que el producto que ofrece es D. calidad y muy limpio. Al momento D. solicitar este préstamo se siente  contenta. A futuro desea comprar en mayores volúmenes. También espera darles a sus hijos la oportunidad D. estudiar para que tengan una mejor calidad D. vida, ya que ella no tuvo oportunidad D. asistir a la escuela. 
L. otros integrantes del grupo son:
1. María D. Jesús A.V 			Venta D. ropa típica
2. Juana T.F 				Venta D. ajo
3. María Frida P.P 			Venta D. artícuL. D. curación y D. farmacia
4. Gregoria Magdalena S.G  		Venta D. verduras
5. Hortencia Feliciana M.R 		Venta D. ajos en tianguis
6. Alma Rosa M. F. 			Venta D. productos lácteos
7. Graciela Roberta T.S  		Venta D. ropa típica
8. Elia Teresa G.M 			Venta D. ropa típica
9. Martha Hilda P. B 			Venta D. especies en tianguis
texts.en:
This group, consisting of 10 members, is called Tlacpacame which means “Those on Top” in Náhuatl, their native tongue. It is located in the Mexican state of Puebla. Josefina G.M., 49, is group president. She has never gone to school, is married, is a merchant and has 9 children, 5 girls and 4 boys, of which three are still minors economically dependent on her. She is a garlic merchant. She started her business over 15 years ago since the community she belongs to is known nationally as a great garlic producer. In fact, you can perceive the aroma of garlic merely by walking along its streets. She is asking for funds to buy garlic at wholesale at a good price that will allow her to make better profits. Her customers are of the opinion that the product she offers is of high quality and very clean. At the time of requesting the loan she feels happy. She hopes in the future to buy larger amounts. She also hopes to proviD. her children with the opportunity to study so that they can have a better quality of life since she did not have the opportunity to go to school. The other group members are: 1. María D. Jesús A.V Typical clothing sales 2. Juana T.F Garlic sales 3. María Frida P.P Pharmacy and sale of curative items 4. Gregoria Magdalena S.G Vegetable sales 5. Hortencia Feliciana M.R Garlic sales at open-air markets 6. Alma Rosa M. F. Dairy products sales 7. Graciela Roberta T.S Typical clothing sales 8. Elia Teresa G.M Typical clothing sales 9. Martha Hilda P. B Spice sales at open-air markets

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy garlic at wholesale.

loans.name: Boriya

texts.en:
Boriya E. is 56 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Baganuur, an outskirt district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own apartment. His two sons attend an occupational-training center, while his wife helps with his business. 

Boriya owns and operates his own shoe-repair business. He began his business in 1998 and has since gained much working experience, which gives him greater access to more customers. His dream is to grow his business so that he and his family can build their own shop with a set of services. 

Boriya is a modest, honest and responsible person. He is requesting a 600,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to buy more repair supplies and tools for his business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies and tools

loans.name: Sonim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sonim S. (pictured here), and her husband, Mr. Socheat Yum, have been married since 2001 and have three young daughters. All of the children are in school. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about twenty kilometers from the city. 

Mrs. Sonim S. has been a garment factory worker for more than ten years. Her husband is a teacher. The couple has plot of the land and they want to operate a rice-growing business. But, they have no time and they are busy with their work.  

For this reason, Sonim is applying for her second loan of $1,200 to hire the fellow villagers to grow rice and to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm.

loans.use: To use for growing rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her arable land and buy fertilizers for her soil

loans.name: Tusiampei  Ene

texts.en:
Tusiampei Ene K. is 49 years old and she supports the three members of her family. Her spouse is Kumpash K. and they are blessed with one child. She does wheat farming, which she has been doing for the last three years successfully due to good climatic conditions and a ready market for the produce in her area. This being her second loan, she is planning to spend 30,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy fertilizer and chemicals for her ten acre wheat farm and the remaining 20,000 KES on spraying the wheat.

Her plan for the anticipated profit is that she will expand her wheat farming to large scale farming. Her hope and dream is that she will become a large scale farmer and own some farm machinery. She is a hardworking woman and determined to achieve her set target.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and chemicals for her wheat farm

loans.name: Maria Hilda

texts.es:
María es una persona responsable y trabajadora tiene 33 años de edad es madre soltera tiene un hijo de 14 años ella vive con su padre en Viloma un cantón del municipio de Sipe Sipe de la provincia de Quillacollo a 20 kilómetros de la ciudad de Cochabamba.

Ella se dedica a la producción de leche ya como quince años atrás desde que su mamá murió ella se ocupo de la producción de la leche y también de la salud de su padre que es una persona mayor que ya no puede trabajar y es por esa razón que ella lo cuida por ser la hermana menor y de ser la única mujer en la familia, María es una mujer trabajadora ella se levanta muy temprano para ordeñar a las vacas y entregar la leche al modulo de la zona, como también se dedica a la agricultura al sembrado de cebollas y zanahorias por temporadas.

Es muy dedicada a su trabajo pero no descuida la educación de su hijo al cual lo va apoyando constantemente en el colegio y el sueña con que su hijo pueda ingresar a la universidad y hacer una carrera ella quiere que el estudie medicina y de esa forma poder ayudar a las personas de la comunidad en la que vive al ser una zona muy alejada y ser personas de escasos recursos.

Ella pide el crédito para la compra de ganado para poder aumentar la producción y entregar más leche al modulo y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ingresos y poderle ofrecer un futuro mejor a su hijo y una vejes mas cómoda a su padre ya que el siempre trabajo por sus hermanos y ella, es por esa razón que ella es dedicada para ser mejor cada día.
texts.en:
Maria is 33 years old, a hard-working, responsible woman. She is a single mom, and has a 14-year-old son. She lives with her father in Viloma, a canton of the Sipe Sipe municipality, province of Quillacolla, 20 km. from Cochabamba. For the past fifteen years, she has worked in dairy, since her mother died. She also sees to her father’s well-being, as he is elderly and can no longer work. That’s why she takes care of him, for she is the youngest sibling, and the only woman in the family.
