HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Dong

texts.en: Dong T. D. is 57 years old and has for the last seven years made a living by providing health care to pets and livestock. Her business, which has been helped by microfinance loans from our organization, is growing quickly and gives her an income of 3,500,000 VND a month. She has repaid her previous loans on time and is applying for a new one, for 8,502,000 VND, to buy equipment for her veterinary practice.

loans.use: to buy some equipment and medications for a veterinary practice

loans.name: Gulnarkan's Group

texts.en: This group consists of five ambitious individual entrepreneurs and colleagues. They are all involved in clothing retail and support each other in repaying the loan. Gulnarkan K., 50, is a leader of this group. She’s a resident of one of the five largest towns in the Jalalabad province. She lives with her husband, who is a private entrepreneur as a city cab driver, and with a 16-year-old daughter, who goes to high school. Gulnarkan has always been characterized by her friends and relatives as a person with a fighting spirit and a big desire to move forward. She says these precise features helped her to start up a women’s apparel retail business. Being a business-lady, she truly realizes the importance of the environment in business. She always hopes to have political and economic stability in Kyrgyzstan. This knowledge is due to her original profession in economics. Many years ago she used to work as an economist in a plant, but soon it stopped functioning and forced her to go into the business sphere. Six years ago, Gulnarakan spent 300,000 soms form the family budget to build a shop. She attaches high importance to how the shop looks and has decorated it carefully. Now she gains the fruits of her labor by 15,000 soms of monthly income. Gulnarkan applied for this loan with the belief that it’ll help her to increase her stock. The generated revenue will be spent on construction of a house. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Melina

texts.es:
La señora Melina es socia del banco comunal La Lupuna, del Distrito de Manantay, Departamento de Ucayali, tiene 34 años de edad, está casada y tiene 3 hijos menores de edad.  Su esposo también está en el mismo negocio.

Ella se dedica a la compra y venta de madera, hace tres años está en este rubro, se inició con un primer préstamo de  S/. 300.00 nuevos soles. Con este nuevo préstamo de S/.1,700.00 nuevos soles, comprara un lote de 1000, pies de  madera capirona.
La vida de la señora Melina ha mejorado en todos estos años que viene trabajando, ahora tiene algunas comodidades  en su hogar, puede dar a sus hijos una mejor educación ya que ahora hay 2 ingresos de dinero.
"..gracias a Manuela Ramos por haberme dado un pequeño capital".
texts.en:
Melina is a member of La Lupina communal bank in the Manantay district, Ucayali department.  She is 34, married and has 3 young children.  Her husband is in the same business.
She has been buying and selling wood for the last 3 years.  She started with her first loan of 300 new sols.  With this new loan of 1700 sols she will buy a lot of 1000 feet of capirona (a tropical tree) wood.  Her life has improved in the years that she has been working.  Now she has some conveniences in her home and she can give her children a better education since there are 2 incomes.
“thanks to Manuela Ramos for having given me a little capital”.

loans.use: To buy a parcel of timber

loans.name: Felicitas Pacion's Group

texts.en:
Felicitas P. is from the village of Bantay Solana, Cagayan. She is 40 years old. Felicitas is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is  "Felicitas P.'s Group".

Felicitas is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Felicitas owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Felicitas has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her raised pigs.

In 2011, Felicitas joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felicitas is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Felicitas from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Lesbia Auxiliadora

texts.es:
Lesbia Auxiliadora T. V., es viuda con tres hijos pero ninguno dependen de ella solamente tiene un nieto que esta bajo su cargo en edad escolar al que tiene el deber de mantener en sus estudios. Se dedica a atender su propio negocio desde hace 10 años en la ciudad de Managua.Desde que inicio el negocio doña Lesbia se ha caracterizado por ser una persona esforzada y eficiente, ella inicio su negocio vendiendo ambulante y desde  entonces a mantenido su negocio y su núcleo familiar gracias a los múltiples esfuerzo.
 Una de las necesidades que atraviesa ella es la urgencia de comprar los productos de su negocio como lo son; ropa y calzado, entre otros. Es  por este motivo que acude a cerpodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito que le permita comprar  productos a sus proveedores y así continuar comercializándolos para satisfacer las demanda de sus clientes con el único fin de obtener los ingresos para mantener su hogar  continuar brindándole la educación a su nieto.  Ha trabajado siete créditos con ceprodel todos para su negocio.
texts.en:
Lesbia Auxiliadora T. V. is a widow with three children, but none of them are dependents. She only has a school age grandson who is under her care, so she has the duty to support his studies. Lesbia has managed her own business in the city of Managua for ten years. Ever since starting her business, Doña Lesbia has been known for being a determined and efficient person. She works as a traveling merchant and has been able to maintain both her business and her family through her many efforts.

One of her urgent needs is to buy products for her business such as clothing, shoes, and other items. For this reason, she has approached CEPRODEL to benefit from a loan that will allow her to acquire products from her distributors and continue selling them so that she can satisfy the demand of her customers. As a result, she will be able to generate the income needed to maintain her household and continue supporting her grandson’s education. Lesbia has received seven loans from CEPRODEL. All of them have been used for her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing, shoes, and other products.

loans.name: Paix Plus Group

texts.en: Evelyne is the leader of the community bank named Paix Plus, which means "peace" in English. The group is made up of 10 members firmly united to receive loans from Kiva through the MFI (microfinance institution) HOPE RDC in order to develop their businesses. Evelyne’s main business is selling loaves of bread in her area west of Kinshasa. Since 2004, she has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to achieve her dream of one day opening a large bread facility. She would also like to achieve financial independence through her business that earns her $50 per week. She works to the best of her abilities and uses her contacts so that she might achieve her goals. Evelyne is a trustworthy client of HOPE RDC, having seven times obtained and correctly repaid loans. She will increase her stock of products with her next loan by buying 40 trays of loaves of bread and reselling them at a profit. Evelyne is 40 years old, married and has five children whose ages vary between 4 and 11 years old. Four of the children go to school.

loans.use: to reinforce her working capital and purchase 40 trays of loaves of bread to resell them at a profit

loans.name: Yesenia Maricela

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Damas Positivas.

La señora Yesenia fue socia fundadora del Banco comunal pero se retiro por unos ciclos y volvió hace tres ciclos,  le gusta el banco por las facilidades para conseguir los créditos. Tiene 28 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene dos hijos de seis y cuatro años de edad, el mayor estudia en  escuela. Su esposo es taxista.

Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo y de cosméticos, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su  casa donde tiene un pequeño local. Trabaja tres días a la semana  desde las 8h00  hasta 11h00, sus productos los  deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a  Guayaquil una vez al mes. Tiene siete  años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas, cosméticos y ropa de niños.

Su sueño es tener un gran local.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the "Damas Positivas" (Positive Ladies) community bank meet in the city of Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí.  For many years, this city has been known as the City of the Royal Tamarind Trees.

Yesenia was a founding member of her community bank but she withdrew for a few loan cycles and then re-joined three cycles ago.  She likes the bank for the ease with which she can obtain loans.  She is 28 years old, married, and has two children aged six and four.  Her eldest child is in elementary school.  Her husband is a taxi driver.

Yesenia sells all kinds of clothes and also cosmetics.  She makes her sales door to door and also sells from her home where she has a small sales location.  She works three days a week, from 8.00am to 11.00am.  She leaves her products with her customers on credit and collects payment every two weeks.  She buys her merchandise in Guayaquil once a month.  Yesenia has been in this business for seven years and it is doing very well.

Yesenia will use this loan to buy more merchandise such as pants, blouses, t-shirts, cosmetics and children's clothes.  Her dream is to own a large sales location.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics, pants, blouses, t-shirts and children's clothes

loans.name: Kulsun's Group

texts.en:
Kulsun is the leader of this group. She is 53 and married to beekeeper. She has raised three daughters and a son with her husband. Her son serves in the army, her youngest daughter graduates school this year, and her other two daughters are married and live with their families. Kulsun works as a teacher in the Education Centre, where she teaches children how to sew clothes. In order to contribute additional money to her family's budget she sells 9-10 liters of milk every day (for 9 soms per liter). Through this business, she earns 2000 soms.  With the money gained from milk sales Kulsun purchases livestock to breed. She is requesting this loan to purchase a bull-calf to breed. In the future, Kulsun wants to see her son get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a bull-calf.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en: Fred is a Ugandan male aged 51 years who needs a loan to buy cattle for resale, a business he has operated for five years. He hails from Kyenjojo district, a father of three children, and has a wife who is a farmer in the same area.  He lives in a semi-permanent house with five people that he takes care of and he dreams of educating his children. He acquired his initial capital from farming to start off the cattle trade and faces a problem of transporting his cattle to the market and he longs to buy a truck to use in transport in future.

loans.use: To buy cattle for resale.

loans.name: Marco Antonio

texts.es: El señor Marco Antonio es carpintero y tiene un pequeño taller de carpintería. El crédito lo requiere para la compra de madera para aumentar el capital de trabajo, pues ha recibido algunos contratos y necesita terminarlos.   Vive en casa de sus padres ubicada en la zona de Alto Irpavi de la ciudad de La Paz, es soltero y no tiene hijos. Esta es la primera vez que solicita crédito y el análisis de su flujo de fondos indica que está en posibilidades de pagar dicho crédito.
texts.en:
Sr. Marco Antonio is a carpenter and has a small workshop. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy wood so that he can increase his operating capital. He has already received a few contracts and needs to fulfill them. Marco lives at his parents’ house in the District of Alto Irpavi in the city of La Paz. He is single and has no children.

This is the first time Marco has requested a loan. The analysis of his cash flow indicates that he is capable of repaying this loan.

loans.use: to purchase wood and other materials for his carpentry business.

loans.name: Tlayecac Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Tlayecac, se encuentra localizado en la comunidad de Tlayecac, en el estado de Morelos, México, está conformado por la señora Marcela va a comprar con su crédito estambres y servilletas para tejer, la señora Beda va a comprar semilla de sorgo para sembrar y cosechar, las señoras Ambrosia y Alma Delia van a comprar huevo, jabón, azúcar, leche y sabritas, la señora Yolanda va a comprar chicharrones y dulces, las señoras Alicia, Yadira y María Luisa van a comprar masa, carne, verduras y tortillas para preparar sus alimentos, la señora Cira va a comprar blusas, pantalones y faldas. La señora Alma Delia tiene 26 años de edad, ella estudio hasta el 6º. Año de primaria, ella vive en unión libre y tiene una hija se llama María de los Ángeles de 5 años de edad esta en preescolar, ella tiene una tienda de abarrotes se llama “Abarrotes Lupita”, ella solicito su crédito para comprar jabón, cloro, aceite, azúcar, huevo, leche para surtir su tienda, ella inicio su negocio hace 1 año se lo traspaso su cuñada, su esposo le compro la mercancía para surtir su tienda para tener mercancía para ofrecerle a sus cliente ella los trata bien con amabilidad para que regresen a comprar, su negocio es importante porque de ahí tiene para la comida,  tiene tiempo para atender a su hija, ella está pensando ampliar su negocio meter productos de papelería, lápices, libretas, gomas, sacapuntas y lo piensa lograr con las ganancias de la tienda, su esposo le ayuda en el negocio va a comprar mercancía, la acomoda y atiende a los clientes, sus sueños y esperanzas son seguir con el negocio de la tienda de abarrotes para el futuro de su hija, construir un cuartito para la cocina. Ella está muy feliz con este préstamo porque va a comprar mercancía para surtir su tienda. Tlayecac es un pueblo bonito, tranquilo, hay campo siembran sorgo, maíz, cebolla, cilantro. Las integrantes del grupo quieren decirle a Kiva y a Fundación Realidad “gracias por esta oportunidad, gracias a sus préstamos nuestros negocio crecen y le dan fuerza con sus apoyos, vamos a salir adelante”. En la foto falta la señora Maria Luisa
texts.en:
The solidarity group named “Tlayecac” is located in the community of Tlayecac in the State of Morelos, Mexico. Listed below are the group members and the purpose of their loans:

• Sra. Marcela will buy napkins and yarn for knitting. • Sra. Beda will buy sorghum seeds that she can plant and harvest. • Sras. Ambrosia and Alma Delia will buy eggs, soap, sugar, milk, and snacks. • Sra. Yolanda will buy pork rinds and candy. • Sras. Alicia, Yadira, and María Luisa will buy cornmeal, meat, vegetables, and tortillas for preparing their dishes. • Sra. Cira will buy blouses, trousers, and skirts.

Sra. Alma Delia is 26 years old and has a sixth grade education. She is in a common-law marriage and has a five-year-old daughter named María de los Ángeles, who is attending preschool. Alma Delia manages a grocery store called “Abarrotes Lupita”. She is requesting a loan to buy soap, bleach, oil, sugar, eggs, and milk so that she can restock her store. Alma Delia started her business a year ago after she took it over from her sister-in-law. Her husband buys the merchandise to restock the store and then she offers it to her customers. She provides friendly service so that her customers will return and continue to shop. Her business is important because it enables her to buy food and also set aside time to look after her daughter. Alma Delia is thinking about expanding her business to include stationery, pencils, notebooks, erasers, and pencil sharpeners so that her store can generate more income. Her husband helps with buying the merchandise, displaying the products, and attending to the customers.

Her hopes and dreams include continuing with her grocery business so that she can provide for her daughter’s future. In addition, she wants to build a small room to use as a kitchen. She is very happy with this loan because she can purchase merchandise to restock her store.

Tlayecac is a beautiful and peaceful town where farmers grow sorghum, corn, onions, and cilantro. The members of this group would like to say to Kiva and Fundación Realidad, “Thank you for this opportunity and providing us loans for our businesses so that they can grow. By giving us strength through this support, we can move forward.” Sra. Maria Luisa is the group member who is missing in the photograph.

loans.use: to purchase soap, bleach, oil, sugar, eggs, and milk.

loans.name: Hiep

texts.en:
Hiep, a 40-year-old married woman, lives in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband buys and sells goods in the local market. Hiep earns income to support her family by sewing clothes and selling fabric to people in the local community.

Hiep requires a loan to purchase better quality fabric and clothing materials that will enable her to make better clothes and provide a better quality service for her customers. She hopes that better materials will permit her to make more beautiful clothing and to attract more customers.

loans.use: to purchase better quality fabric and clothing materials

loans.name: Gerardo Rafael

texts.es: El Señor Gerardo tiene como actividad la venta de mercadería en general actividad que realiza desde hace mas 3 años, las ventas las realiza de manera ambulante sale a tocar de puerta en puerta para ofrecer la variedad de productos que tiene. Trabaja todos los días desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche, que llega a su casa cansado de realizar diferentes recorridos. Es por eso que solicita este crédito para la compra de pantalones, camisas, faldas, vestidos, trajes y cosméticos. Sueña con aumentar su inventario y proporcionar mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en: Gerardo works selling general merchandise and has been in this business for more than three years.  He is traveling salesman who goes door-to-door to sell a variety of products.  He works every day from 7am to 9pm and is tired when he arrives home from traveling the various routes.  This is why he is requesting this loan for the purchase of pants, shirts, skirts, dresses, suits and cosmetics.  He dreams of increasing his inventory and making housing improvements.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, skirts, dresses, suits and cosmetics.

loans.name: Medonald

texts.en: Medonald is 22 years old. She has two children. One of her children is in school. She is a married woman. She requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business. She will use the profit from her business to pay the school fees of her child.

loans.use: to purchase more breads and cake to sell

loans.name: Claudelina

texts.es:
La Señorita Claudelina tiene 29 años de edad, es soltera, tiene una hija con la cual vive en la ciudad Villarrica, tiene casa propia, ofrece servicios de peluquería en su local propio y a domicilio.
Ella se define como una mujer muy sacrificada y luchadora. Su principal objetivo es brindarle un mejor porvenir a su hija. Comenta que desea que su hija tenga un mejor futuro que al que ella pudo acceder, ya que tuvo que pasar muchas necesidades. Desea poder ampliarse en el negocio de la peluquería, por lo que se esfuerza más y más.
En cuanto a la clientela dice que muchas mujeres del barrio acuden a ella para solicitarle su servicio. Como hace un tiempo se dedica a esto ya posee muchos clientes.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de los insumos necesarios para su peluquería, como ser spray, gel, tintes, y otros químicos. Está muy esperanzada en el crédito, ya que de obtenerlo le será de mucha ayuda.
texts.en:
Srta. Claudelina is 29 years old, single, and lives with her daughter in their own home in the city of Villarrica. She has a beauty salon in her home where she offers her services.

Claudelina defines herself as self-sacrificing and determined woman. Her main goal is to provide a better future for her daughter. She says that she wants her daughter to have a better future because she has many needs. In addition, Claudelina wants to expand her beauty salon business so that it can get stronger.

As for her customers, Claudelina says that there are many women in her neighborhood who come to her to request her services. Over time, she has acquired many customers. She is requesting a loan to buy necessary supplies for her salon such as hair spray, gel, dyes, and other chemicals. Claudelina is very hopeful that the loan she obtained will be of great help.

loans.use: to buy hair spray, gel, dyes, and other chemicals.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase construction materials so that he can continue building a wall  at the other end of his house

loans.name: Crescencio

texts.es:
Don Crescencio tiene 54 años de edad está casado con la señora Aurelia desde hace 35 años Aun tienen un niño que está estudiando la preparatoria tiene 16 años claro tuvo más hijos pero ya no dependen de él ya que todos están casados, prácticamente en casa ya solo viven él y su esposa.
El se dedica a la elaboración de trajecitos deportivos, chalequitos de lana, esta vez solicita el crédito para comprar materia prima hilo, raseros, mallas, agujas.
El comenta que en la actividad lleva ya 20 años con ésta actividad, desde muy pequeño aprendío a hacerlo.
Los problemas que enfrenta es cuando las ventas bajan porque hace mucho calor. 
La única esperanza que tiene don Crescencio es que pueda apoyar a su hijo que está estudiando todavía en la prepa ya que le gustaría fuera un gran profesionista
“Estoy muy agradecido con ayuda y confianza que depositan en mi”
texts.en:
Crescencio is 54 years old. He has been married to Aurelia for 35 years. They have a 16-year-old son who is in high school. Of course he had more children, but they don't depend on him anymore, because they are all married. He and his wife are practically the only ones living at his home now.
He manufactures sports clothing and woolen vests. This time he requests the loan in order to purchase supplies such as thread, measuring sticks, mesh and needles.
He says that he has already been in this business for 20 years; he learned it when he was very young.
The problems he faces come when sales are down because the weather is very hot.
Crescencio's only hope is to be able to support his son who's still in high scholl, because he would like his son to be a great professional.
"I'm very thankful for the help and the trust deposited in me".

loans.use: to purchase fabric, thread, needles, wool and fabric dye.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is a 35-year-old married woman with five children; three of whom are in the school. She has a business of selling clothes in the Hai Mahad branch in Yei South Sudan. She has been in this business for six years.

Charity requested this loan through BRAC South Audan to be able to purchase more clothes for sale. The extra income she earns will be used for paying school fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: In the photo, Nana is sitting amidst some dried copra which she is cutting to dry and to make coconut oil. She also makes palm oil for sale. Nana is married and has 4 children. Her husband is a farmer. Nana's income is used to help pay the children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy coconut fruit to make into oil to sell. Nana anticipates reinvesting the profit.

loans.use: to buy coconut fruit to make into oil to sell

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita is 48 years old and lives in Upper Langcangan, Oroquieta City. She is married with three children. 
Florita's business is to buy and sell rice and corn and she earns approximately PHP 2,000 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of  PHP 5,000 to purchase 3 sacks of rice for her retail business.
Florita has been a member of PMPC for a month.

loans.use: to purchase 3 sacks of rice for her retail business.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a hardworking business man, aged 29. He is married and blessed with two children who are in school. He does photography to earn a living. His potential customers are residents of his locality. James has employed one person to help him to run the business. In the next 5 years, he wants to expand his business and employ more people. He has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy a camera.

loans.use: To buy a camera.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is from Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Fe is married and has one child. 

To earn a living, Fe operates a business venture, raising pigs for sale. Fe has been in business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Fe is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP that will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. In 2011, Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve both her business and her living situation. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the loan as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Azela

texts.en:
Azela is 28 years old and is married with two children aged between 3 and 5 years old. Her business is well, clean and good. She sells notebooks, pens, books, etc., in her stationery store. She has two years experience in this business. Her business starts from 8 a.m. until 5 p.m. all week except on Sunday. 

Azela has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her stationery store by buying more goods such as notebooks, pens, books, etc., in her store for resale. With any profit from the loan, Azela will expand her business and save for her family.

loans.use: To expand her stationery store by buying more goods such as notebooks, pens, books, etc., in her store for resale.

loans.name: Roquilio

texts.en:
Roquilio is a married man with six children between the ages of 9 and 20. He is a fisherman working in Talibon, Bohol. Roquilio earns 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) per month with his business. He works hard to support his family and send his children to school. 

Roquilio has requested a loan to purchase fishing nets, hooks and other materials. Roquilio hopes to have a stable income. He also plans to improve their house.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets, hooks and other materials

loans.name: Corethe

texts.en: Corethe is 55 years old and has five children aged 19 to 32. The youngest child is currently in school. She sells foodstuffs in a store she has run for 10 years. With the requested loan, she would like to buy more sorghum and beans to sell. Corethe will use any profits to provide for her family and create savings. Her dream is to one day own a guest house.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 58 years old married to Matene. They are blessed with three children. She has been in the dairy farming business for the past five years with a monthly income of KES 5,000, which she uses to support her family.

She is applying for her first loan with KADET after being introduced by an existing KADET customer. Margaret will use the loan to buy animal feeds and a beehive. With the anticipated profit from the business, she will educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to keep bees in large scale and be a honey distributor.

loans.use: To buy animal feeds and a beehive.

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba is married to a capernter and lives with their 4 children at Benkyadze near Elmina. Araba sells doughnut and maize porridge which she has done for some time now. Araba uses her income to support her husband and to pay utility bills. Araba will use her loan to purchase flour and maize for the preparation of her doughnut and maize porridge to sell. Araba will expand her business with the new profits.

loans.use: to purchase flour and maize for the preparation of her doughnut and maize porridge to sell.

loans.name: Stephen Otieno

texts.en:
Stephen is 25 years and was born Kibuye Village in Nakuru County. He is married with children and is engaged in retail small scale business. Stephen wants to make a difference in his community and town of nakuru by engaging community health outreach programme run by a Community Based Organization CBO in Nakuru 

He has also committed to spend most of his free time with the CHW counseling the youth on avoiding anti social practices, drug abuse and AIDs/HIV prevention and engaging in sports. Stephen is happy to own his own motorcycle and is ready to give back to the community as a trainee CHW volunteer in 2014.

Stephen will also use the income generated from his motorcycle business to support his family, he plans to buy another motorcycle and support more CHWs in future.

loans.use: To pay for motorcycle for Community Health Work and Livelihoods

loans.name: Muvakani Mbukilye S.h.g Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Josephine. She is fifty two years old, married and a mother of five children. She is a member of Muvakani Mbukilye S.H.G which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in order to benefit from enterprise development and financial management training.

She does maize, beans and poultry farming. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer and pesticides. This will greatly boost her farming hence increased income which will enable her cater for her children’s clothing, food and school fees.
She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs such as fertilizer and pesticides hence more income to cater for her children's clothing, food and school fees.

loans.name: Araceli Margarita

texts.en:
Eight years ago Araceli started selling shoes by catalogue, given the necessity to support her husband, a painter working for a company, although the employment does not yield much profit. She is mother of two children that are still underage. They live in the city of Escobedo in the state of Nuevo Leon. Thanks to Araceli's business, her children have been able to have what they need and this is why she works hard day after day, to maintain and expand what she has built with such great effort.

Today she needs a loan in the amount of $275 to purchase merchandise in greater volumes and this way increase her roster of clients, and her income. You can be an important part of Araceli and her family's success. They will sincerely thank you.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Hace 8 años Araceli inició con la venta de zapatos por catálogo, por la necesidad de apoyar a su esposo, ya que se desempeña como pintor en una empresa constructora y esta actividad no le genera muchos recursos. Ella es madre de dos hijos, quienes aún son menores de edad y vive en la localidad de Escobedo, en el estado de Nuevo León. Gracias al proyecto de Araceli, sus hijos han podido tener lo necesario, es por ello que día a día lucha para mantener y hacer crecer lo que con tanto esfuerzo ha logrado construir.

En este momento ella requiere de un préstamo por la cantidad de $275 DLLS, para poder comprar una mayor cantidad de mercancía y de esta manera incrementar su cartera de clientes y por ende sus ingresos. Tú puedes se parte importante de los logros de Araceli y su familia ellos te lo agradecen sinceramente.

loans.use: purcahse merchandise

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Natalya runs a small business selling just about a little bit of everything. From telephones, tea pots and curling irons, to manicure sets, writing pens and women’s purses, she has been able to build her business by marketing those practical items that everybody can use. She operates from a little space at an indoor mall in Nikopol, Ukraine. Before starting her own business, Natalya worked as a salesperson for another store. This gave her valuable retailing experience which has benefited her as she has started her own enterprise. The assistance she has gained through loans from “Nadiya Ukraine” has also helped in her business development. Available funding has enabled her to maintain stability and growth. Natalya has requested a loan that will enable her to purchase additional inventory in bulk. She is always on the lookout for good prices from suppliers that will give her the ability to make a profit. By having an adequate amount of capital available, she can maximize her opportunities and continue developing a solid business.

В Наталії є власний невеличкий бізнес. Вона торгує усім потроху, починаючи з телефонів, чайників, прасок для волосся і закінчуючи манікюрними наборами, ручками та жіночими сумочками. Бізнес Наталії, розташований в торговому центрі в м Нікополь, розвивався завдяки торгівлі усіма цими практичними товарами. До того, як почати власний бізнес Наталія працювала продавцем в крамниці. Завдяки цій роботі вона отримала необхідний досвід роздрібної торгівлі, який знадобився їй, коли вона починала власну справу. Позики, які Наталія отримала від „Надії України”, також сприяли розвитку її бізнесу. Додаткові кошти дали їй можливість досягти стабільності та отримати додаткові прибутки. Наталія просить про позику, яка допоможе їй закупити товар оптом. Вона завжди уважно слідкує за цінами постачальників, низькі закупівельні ціни допомагають їй отримати прибуток від продажу. Отримавши необхідні додаткові кошти, Наталія зможе реалізувати власні можливості й надалі розвивати стабільний бізнес.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Kankoé

texts.fr:
Kankoe A., age 27, is a young kerosene merchant in the village of Aklakou, where he lives with his family of five people. The place where he sells kerosene for lamps is out in the open, under the hot sun. He is often obliged to buy on credit and repay after he sells the kerosene. That system does not permit him to make enough profit to support his family and improve his business premises. The need to build a shed to sell out of and to pay upfront for the kerosene leads him to ask for a loan of US$ 1200. Finding financing for these improvements in his business will allow him to flourish and to better provide for his family.

Translated from the French by Teresa Kramer, KIVA volunteer

Age de 27 ans, M. A. Kankoé est un jeune commerçant de pétrole lampant dans le village d’Aklakou ou il vit avec toute sa famille de cinq personnes. Son point de vente de pétrole est à l’air libre sous le chaud soleil et lui-même s’approvisionne souvent à crédit et rembourse après la vente. Ce système ne lui permet pas de dégager un bénéfice significatif pour subvenir au besoin de sa famille et réaliser ses projets. La nécessité de construire un hangar et de s’approvisionner au comptant en pétrole l’amène à demander un crédit de $1200. Le financement de ce projet lui permettra de s’épanouir et de mieux supporter les lourdes charges de son ménage.

loans.use: Buying and selling kerosene for lamps

loans.name: Chanda

texts.en:
“With my husband’s rickshaw (a local three-wheeled vehicle), we are fortunate enough to be able to send our four children to school. My husband bought the rickshaw and now we require a loan for its maintenance. A well-maintained rickshaw will help bring in more business and allow him to operate for long hours. We hope to keep his business going so that our children can continue with their education”


Chanda B., Pakistan

loans.use: For the maintenance of a rickshaw (a local three-wheeled vehicle)

loans.name: Mathius

texts.en:
Mathius K. is a 40 year-old married man. He has five children of his own and cares for his brothers' five children.

For a living, Mathius sells charcoal. He has a 20’ x 20’ log rail, fenced corral covered by a roof of corrugated steel. His business is located in the heart of the Rubaga District of Kampala, reachable only by winding dirt paths. Currently, within the gated corral, he has a stack of 15 charcoal bags, each bag weighing approximately 110 kg. People enter the corral with one gallon plastic jugs and Mathius fills the single jug with charcoal. They will use this as fuel in their cooking pots which are placed outside their homes in Rubaga.

Mathius is gentle and well-known in Rubaga, for everyone cooks with charcoal. He has been selling charcoal for approximately 20 years and calls Rubaga his home. He does not dream of ever leaving Rubaga. However, he does dream of buying a plot of land with 10’ x 15’ dimensions to build a house.

With the loan, he wants to buy more charcoal. If he can buy in larger quantities, he will spend less time having to make trips to get the charcoal. He is increasing his sales to small hotels and restaurants in the area. These are one and two room dirt floor “hotels” and “restaurants” with outdoor cooking pots, tables and chairs.

(If you would like to learn more, please check out the Fellows Blog: The Women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of charcoal, thus reducing the number of trips he makes to get the charcoal.

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.es:
Mrs. Bendicta lives in her parents’ house in the area of Llojeta ladera oeste of the City La Paz with her husband and three children; Benedicta works as a teacher in a neighborhood center and her husband works in a detergent factory. With past savings and past loans they have been able to buy a lot close to where they live now. This new credit will be used to build one room in the lot that will eventually over time become their new home. This is the third time that she is asking for a loan and the credit analysis performed shows that she is a favorable candidate and that she should be capable of repaying this new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Felipe Salcedo, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Benedicta vive en casa de sus padres en la zona de Llojeta ladera oeste de la Ciudad de La Paz, con su esposo y tres hijos; Benedicta trabaja como educadora en un centro comunal de su zona y su esposo es empleado en una fábrica de detergentes. Con ahorros generados en los últimos años y el apoyo de créditos anteriores pudieron concluir la compra de un terreno en la misma zona. El crédito solicitado será destinado a la construcción de una habitación en el terreno nuevo que formara parte su vivienda propia. Esta es la tercera vez que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califica favorablemente y puede acceder a un crédito.

loans.use: To build one room
